page.title: 18LAND USE
page.content: Much of the land is uncultivated open moorland used by crofters as common grazing for black face sheep.An annual unorganised muirburn takes place each spring to encourage young heather growth for sheep to eat.Bare rock is exposed at many places.Where peat exists close to a road it is cut during May and June to be dried and used as domestic fuel.Much manual effort is involved because the uneven terrain does not permit the use of machinery.The fenced croftland has been improved for grazing by using shell sand from local beaches,and reseeding.Small areas of the poor peaty soil have been formed into lazybeds about 6m wide with drainage ditches running down the slope on either side.Hay,potatoes,and some oats are grown on these lazybeds.
